title: Lawmakers Day 38 03/31/25
text:
lawmakers day 38 03/31/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia legislature floor session transcript:

**overview**
the session on day 38 (03/31/25) of the georgia legislative session saw heated debates on several bills, including the pediatric safe storage act (hb 1), a bill banning transgender athletes from female sports (sb 1), and a bill creating financial incentives for local school boards to approve charter school petitions (sb 82). the session also included the recognition of 33 black legislators elected during reconstruction and the consideration of the state's fiscal year 2026 budget.

**key actions**
- **hb 303**: bill to place a memorial on capitol grounds honoring 33 black legislators elected in 1868 during reconstruction.
- **sb 93**: georgia early literacy act, creating new guidelines for teaching reading to young students.
- **sb 1**: bill banning transgender girls from participating in girls' sports and requiring changing rooms to be separated by sex assigned at birth. passed 100-64.
- **sb 82**: bill creating financial incentives for local school boards to approve petitions for new charter schools and penalizing school systems that repeatedly deny charter school proposals. passed 107-62.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- none mentioned

**notable moments**
- before the presentation of hb 268 (school safety bill), senator bill callisert read the names of appalachia high school shooting victims and asked for a moment of silence.
- democrats opposed sb 1, calling it a "manufactured crisis" and criticizing the bill for targeting individuals rather than addressing real problems.
- republicans argued that sb 1 protects the integrity of women's sports and ensures fair competition.

**votes**
- hb 268 (school safety bill): passed 45-9
- sb 1 (transgender sports ban): passed 100-64
- sb 82 (charter school incentives): passed 107-62

**attendance**
- quorum was present for the proceedings.

**adjournment**
- the session adjourned for the day, with committees scheduled to meet the next day and the house and senate floor sessions scheduled to resume on wednesday. hv1 is a democratic bill called the pediatric safe storage act.

title: Lawmakers Day 32 03/18/25
text:
lawmakers day 32 03/18/25 overview:
- the georgia general assembly session on day 32 (march 18, 2025) saw the introduction of several bills and resolutions, including some controversial measures.
- the session featured debates over bills related to maternal mortality, tax relief for timber farmers, and expanding farmland ownership, as well as resolutions praising republican politicians.

key actions:
- **hb 111**: allows the maternal mortality review committee to access psychiatric and medical records related to maternal mortality cases, in an effort to lower the state's maternal mortality rate.
- **hb 223**: provides tax relief for timber farmers who suffered economic losses from hurricane helene.
- **hb 90**: allows farmers to own up to 4,000 acres of farmland and receive lower tax rates, pending voter approval to change the state constitution.
- **sb 6**: allows the sale of fentanyl test strips to the public and excludes them from drug paraphernalia classification.
- **sb 55**: requires companies to pay georgians with intellectual disabilities at least the minimum wage, phasing out sub-minimum wage programs.

bills introduced (first reading): none mentioned in the transcript.

notable moments:
- governor kemp appointed barbara rivera-holmes as the new commissioner of labor, replacing the late bruce thompson.
- the senate debated and passed resolutions praising former congressman and current va secretary doug collins, as well as president donald trump, despite some democratic opposition.

votes:
- **hr 32 and hb 90**: passed unanimously
- **sr 245 (doug collins)**: passed
- **sr 246 (donald trump)**: passed along party lines 31-18

attendance: no quorum notes mentioned.

title: DBHDD Commissioner on Georgia's Mental Health Issues
text:
dbhdd commissioner on georgia's mental health issues overview:
the key highlights from this session with georgia department of behavioral health and developmental disabilities (dbhdd) commissioner kevin tanner include the agency's role in forensic services, the challenges with limited state hospital beds, and new initiatives to address the needs of individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (idd) who end up in emergency rooms.

key actions:
no bills were discussed or passed in this session.

bills introduced (first reading):
none detected.

notable moments:
- commissioner tanner explained dbhdd's responsibility for determining competency to stand trial and restoring competency for those found incompetent.
- he noted the lack of state hospital beds, with nearly 800 individuals in jail waiting for a bed, and the long wait times of over a year on average.
- tanner discussed plans for a new 16-bed crisis stabilization and diagnostic center for the idd population, which will provide comprehensive medical and psychiatric care.
- he also mentioned opening pilot group homes to step down individuals from hospitals and getting approval from cms for new medicaid placement options for the "hard to place" idd population.
- tanner highlighted workforce challenges, with dbhdd losing over 1,200 employees during covid, and efforts to boost recruitment and retention, including partnerships with universities.

votes:
no votes were mentioned.

attendance:
no specific quorum notes were provided.

title: Lawmakers Day 30 03/11/25
text:
lawmakers day 30 03/11/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers day 30 03/11/25 session:

**overview:**
the georgia house of representatives passed the fy 2026 budget (hb 68), which includes an additional $500 million in education spending and $250 million more for the state's prison system. the session also featured recognitions, including celebrating a member's last radiation treatment and honoring the 50th anniversary of the shepherd center.

**key actions:**
**hb 68:** fiscal year 2026 budget, passed 171-4. includes $500 million more in education spending and $250 million more for the prison system.
**hb 287:** updated dnr fishing and hunting license regulations, passed unanimously.
**hr 97 and hr 98:** regulate sale and leasing of state property and non-exclusive easements, passed unanimously.

**bills introduced (first reading):** none noted.

**notable moments:**
- member celebrated last radiation treatment for cancer.
- house recognized 50th anniversary of shepherd center, which treats brain and spinal cord injuries.
- senate recognized georgia lineworkers and named an interchange after a slain roswell police officer.

**votes:**
- hb 68 (budget): passed 171-4.
- hb 287, hr 97, hr 98: passed unanimously.

**attendance:** quorum present, no issues noted.

title: Conference Committee HB189 - 3/29/23
text:
conference committee hb189 - 3/29/23 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia conference committee hb189 - 3/29/23 session:

**overview**
the session focused on the ongoing discussion and negotiation around hb189, which deals with increasing weight limits for certain agricultural and timber trucks in georgia. the discussion highlighted the need to balance supporting the state's crucial agriculture and forestry industries while also addressing concerns about infrastructure funding and maintenance.

**key actions**
no bills were passed or referred during this session.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
none detected.

**notable moments**
- representative minks opened the session with a prayer.
- representative gooch shared remarks emphasizing the need to work in good faith to find a solution that helps the state's farmers and foresters.
- senate majority leader gooch gave an extensive speech outlining the history of transportation funding challenges in georgia, the importance of infrastructure investment, and the need for a broader, long-term approach beyond just the current hb189 negotiations.
- there was discussion about the provisions in the senate version of hb189, including the one-year extension of increased weight limits, the carve-out for non-attainment counties, increased fines for violations, and allowing local law enforcement to assist with enforcement.
- concerns were raised about potentially losing the bill if drastic changes were made in the conference committee.

no recorded votes were mentioned in the transcript.

title: Sen. Anavitarte Press Conference on Majority Party Priorities | 01/13/2026
text:
sen. anavitarte press conference on majority party priorities | 01/13/2026 overview:
this press conference by georgia senate president pro tempore larry walker outlines the republican majority's legislative priorities for the 2026 session, focused on addressing the high cost of living and reigniting the "american dream" for hardworking georgians.

key actions:
none detected.

bills introduced (first reading):
none detected.

notable moments:
- walker discusses the significance of 2026 being america's 250th birthday, or "semi-quincentennial", and how this will bring patriotic celebrations.
- walker expresses concern that affordability issues have caused many georgians to feel that the "american dream" is slipping beyond their grasp.
- the majority caucus plans to tackle affordability issues and "reignite the american dream" through measures like eliminating the state income tax, providing property tax relief, limiting institutional investors in the housing market, and reforming the home-building permitting process.
- the agenda also includes supporting first responders, preserving natural assets, improving k-12 education and literacy, and addressing challenges like street racing and technology access for children.
- walker criticizes "insane liberal democrat policies" and the biden administration's "crippling inflation" as drivers of the cost of living challenges.

votes:
none detected.

attendance: 
no quorum notes.

text:

## overview

**overview:**
the press conference focused on announcing the filing of senate bill 433, also known as "rio's law", which aims to create a specialty license plate to help law enforcement and first responders better identify and interact with individuals with autism or developmental disabilities during traffic stops and emergencies. the bill also requires basic training for georgia peace officers on how to best interact with these individuals.

**key actions:**
**sb 433 (rio's law):** creates a specialty license plate to help law enforcement and first responders identify individuals with autism or developmental disabilities, and requires basic training for georgia peace officers on interacting with these individuals.

- connor tomlinson, star of the netflix show "love on the spectrum", spoke as an autistic advocate in support of the legislation.
- chairman lumpston of the house pledged to champion the bill in the house, drawing on his own law enforcement experience.

the session featured passionate debates over bills related to transgender healthcare and book banning in libraries. lawmakers also passed the amended mid-year budget and a bill to expand the definition of military bases.

**key actions**
- **hb399**: requires out-of-state landlords owning over 25 single-family homes to have an in-state broker to manage tenant complaints.
- **sb30**: bans all hormone therapies and puberty blocking treatments for minors with gender dysphoria.

- **sb30 (gender dysphoria treatment ban)**: passed 34-19 along party lines.

title: Lawmakers Day 31 03/13/25
text:
lawmakers day 31 03/13/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers day 31 03/13/25 session:

**overview:**
the session featured a mix of lighthearted debates on bills designating official state colors and heritage horses, as well as more serious discussions around school psychologist licensing, pesticide disclosure requirements, and the use of song lyrics as evidence in the high-profile prosecution of rapper young thug.

**key actions:**
**hb 81:** allows school psychologists to work across state lines with equivalent licensing.
**hb 167:** allows the use of fluorescent pink in addition to orange for hunting attire.
**sb 139:** allows the city of mulberry to annex certain parcels of land in gwinnett county.
**sb 138:** waives gwinnett county's sovereign immunity in providing services to mulberry.
**sb 144:** prevents pesticide manufacturers from being held liable for undisclosed health risks beyond fda requirements.

**bills introduced (first reading):** none noted.

**notable moments:**
- debate on the appropriate "shade of pink" to be used for hunting attire.
- democrats opposing the mulberry annexation and gwinnett county service bills, arguing it was a "free berry" approach.
- passionate discussion around the use of song lyrics as evidence in the young thug prosecution, with a democratic representative joining the opposition.

**votes:**
- hb 81 passed 48-2.
- hb 167 passed unanimously.
- sb 139 passed 96-74 along party lines.
- sb 138 passed along party lines.
- sb 144 passed 101-58.

**attendance:** quorum maintained.

title: Lawmakers Day 39 04/02/25
text:
lawmakers day 39 04/02/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia legislature floor session transcript:

**overview**:
this was a busy day 39 of the georgia legislative session, with lawmakers racing to pass as much legislation as possible before the session ends. the session featured partisan debates on voting bills, as well as recognitions and emotional moments around school safety and mental health.

**key actions**:
- **hb 397**: controversial voting bill that passed along party lines, with democrats criticizing it as an attempt to disenfranchise voters.
- **sb 17**: "ricky and lisa's law" adding clarifying language to a school safety bill passed earlier.
- **sb 185**: bill banning state funds for gender-affirming care for transgender prisoners, prompting a walkout by democratic lawmakers in protest.
- **sb 214**: bill requiring paper ballots in elections, which will have to wait until the next session since it missed the crossover day deadline.

**bills introduced (first reading)**: no new bills mentioned.

**notable moments**:
- emotional testimony from a legislator about their child's fear of school shootings.
- georgia first lady marty camp joined the session to discuss the 988 mental health crisis hotline.
- walkout by democratic lawmakers in protest of sb 185.
- recognition of longtime legislative cameraman wesley nichols for his 25 years of service.

**votes**:
- **hb 397**: passed 33-23 along party lines.
- **sb 17**: passed unanimously.
- **sb 185**: passed, prompting a democratic walkout.

**attendance**: no specific quorum notes provided.

title: Lawmakers Day 36 03/27/25
text:
lawmakers day 36 03/27/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers day 36 03/27/25 session:

**overview:** the session was marked by several notable actions, including passing bills to allow terminally ill patients access to experimental treatments, create a scholarship grant program for youth in foster care, and codify access to in vitro fertilization. there was also debate over a bill to criminalize artificial intelligence videos designed to interfere with elections, and a partisan resolution to investigate alleged illegal campaign contributions by the new georgia project.

**key actions:**
- **sb 72:** allows terminally ill patients to access experimental treatments
- **sb 85:** creates a scholarship grant program for georgia youth in foster care
- **sb 233:** adds individuals with first-hand experience with addiction to the behavioral health reform and innovation commission
- **sb 9:** criminalizes artificial intelligence videos designed to interfere with elections (passed 152-12)
- **sb 69:** sets regulations around third parties financing lawsuits (passed 98-69)
- **sb 105:** allows veterinarians to give pet health advice
- **hb 428:** codifies access to in vitro fertilization

**bills introduced (first reading):**
- hb 106, hb 310, hb 423, hb 60

**notable moments:**
- visit from the house speaker's chief of staff, terry england, who was recovering from a farming accident
- debate over sb 9, with arguments that ensuring election integrity is the "most important thing" lawmakers can do for constituents

**votes:**
- sb 9 passed 152-12
- sb 69 passed 98-69
- sb 105 passed unanimously
- hb 428 and an amendment to raise the governor's salary to $250,000 passed 45-10

title: The First Lady of Georgia Chats about GRACE Commission's Work Against Human Trafficking
text:
the first lady of georgia chats about grace commission's work against human trafficking here is a summary of the georgia legislative session on the first lady of georgia chats about grace commission's work against human trafficking:

**overview**: the first lady of georgia, marty kemp, discussed her efforts to raise awareness and take action against human trafficking in the state through the grace commission. she highlighted the pervasive nature of the issue, even in rural areas, and the importance of educating the public and law enforcement to identify and report potential trafficking situations.

**key actions**:
- no specific bills mentioned as being passed or referred.

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
- none detected.

**notable moments**:

title: Lawmakers Day 35 03/25/25
text:
lawmakers day 35 03/25/25 overview:
- the georgia legislature session on march 25, 2025 saw the farewell of senator brandon beach, who was tapped to join the trump administration as the new u.s. treasurer. 
- lawmakers passed several notable bills, including hb 92 extending the deadline for counties and municipalities to opt out or rescind an opt-out of property tax homestead exemptions, and hb 340 banning cell phones in k-8 schools during the school day.
- the session also featured emotional moments, including a tearful thank-you from a representative who was let go from his job after voting against a bill.

key actions:
- **hb 92**: extends deadline for counties/municipalities to opt out or rescind opt-out of property tax homestead exemptions
- **hb 340**: bans cell phones in k-8 schools during school day, allowing school systems to set their own policies
- **sb 123**: defines chronic absenteeism in schools and requires attendance review teams
- **sb 42**: increases penalties for sex trafficking of minors
- **sb 110**: revises definition of child neglect in georgia code

bills introduced (first reading): none mentioned

notable moments:
- tearful farewell from a representative who was let go from his job after voting against a bill
- representative quoted bible verse jeremiah 29:11 after being let go

votes:
- hb 92 passed 52-2
- hb 340 passed 54-2 
- sb 123 passed 160-1
- sb 42 passed unanimously
- sb 110 passed 100-69

title: Capitol Report Day 34 03/21/25
text:
capitol report day 34 03/21/25 ## overview

the georgia legislature session focused on the debate and passage of senate bill 68, a controversial tort reform bill that included an exception for victims of human trafficking. the session featured a failed amendment to extend protections to children and the elderly, as well as concerns raised by a republican senator about the bill being an "insurance company bailout."

## key actions

**sb 68**: tort reform bill, passed 34-21.

## bills introduced (first reading)

no new bills were introduced.

## notable moments

- attempted amendment to extend protections to children and the elderly failed.
- senator colton moore, a republican, criticized the bill as an "insurance company bailout" with no guarantees of lower rates.
- governor brian kemp praised the legislature's work on the "tough issue."

## votes

**sb 68**: passed 34-21.

## attendance

no quorum issues noted.

## adjournment

lawmakers will return on tuesday for day 35 of the session. good evening, i'm sarah callis with the lawmaker's capitol report.

title: Lawmakers 2026 | Day 2: Income Tax Debate and ICE Protections
text:
lawmakers 2026 | day 2: income tax debate and ice protections here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers 2026 | day 2: income tax debate and ice protections session:

## overview
this session focused on legislation related to income taxes, property taxes, and immigration enforcement. senate republicans announced their priorities for the 2026 legislative session, while senate democrats proposed bills aimed at regulating ice agents in georgia.

## key actions
- **sb 204**: originally a democratic bill from 2025 that allowed certain non-violent felonies to be charged by district attorneys without the involvement of a grand jury. the bill was amended to include language from sb 163, which would allow individual gun owners to bring legal action against local governments who they feel infringed on their second amendment rights.
- **sb 389**: proposed by senate democrats, would require ice agents to remove their masks and properly identify themselves during arrests.
- **proposed bills**: democrats also proposed bills to allow civil lawsuits against ice and require a warrant for arrests in schools, hospitals, and churches.

## bills introduced (first reading)
- sb 390: proposed by senate democrats, would require legislative approval for national guard deployment in georgia.
- sb 192: not mentioned in the transcript, but likely introduced during the session.

## notable moments
- senate democrats held a press conference to announce their legislation affecting immigration enforcement, calling for ice agents to "unmask" and be held accountable.
- republican lawmakers criticized the democrats' proposed bills, saying they were unnecessary and that law enforcement leaders should make decisions about tactical gear, not legislators.

## votes
- sb 204 was adopted by substitution in a 32-21 party-line vote, but failed to garner the two-thirds majority needed to be sent immediately to the governor.

## attendance
the transcript does not mention any quorum or attendance issues.

## adjournment
the session adjourned, but the next session date is not specified. music

## overview
the committee discussed several recommendations to simplify, educate, and invest in dual enrollment programs for highly skilled students at younger ages. key focuses were defining "high-demand careers", improving information accessibility, streamlining articulation agreements, and providing more funding for instructors and counselors.

## key actions
none detected

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected

## notable moments
- the committee discussed the need to clearly define "high-demand careers" in statute, and potentially consolidate multiple lists into one.
- there was emphasis on improving accessibility of information about dual enrollment, ctae courses, and accelerated career pathways for parents and students.
- the committee recommended streamlining and encouraging more articulation agreements between school systems, technical colleges, and universities for strategic two-plus-two arrangements.
- the committee discussed removing the sunset provision on senate bill 86 to provide continuity and clarity for the dual enrollment program.
- the importance of data-driven decision making and broad stakeholder collaboration was stressed in the "educate" section.

none detected

title: 3/16/23 - Committee on Rules
text:
3/16/23 - committee on rules overview:
- the georgia legislature's committee on rules session on 3/16/23 was an active one, with the committee members engaged in discussing and advancing several bills.

key actions:
- **hb 493**: allows nurses at veterans' hospitals to use $500 worth of work at their va as continuing education credits, like other state-licensed nurses.
- **hb 35**: expands the georgia ports authority's jurisdiction to one mile beyond port boundaries.
- **hb 76**: renames the "georgia occupational regulation review commission" to the "georgia occupational regulation review council."
- **hb 91**: requires executors to provide notice to beneficiaries and treats investment/brokerage accounts with named beneficiaries like bank accounts.
- **hb 120**: allows people behind on child support to receive temporary driving permits to go back to work, and cleans up language around dui-drug charges and license reinstatement.
- **hb 183**: updates the population bracket identifying butts county to allow georgia power lease-holders on jackson lake to file homestead exemptions.

**overview**
the session focused on passing a senate resolution (sr 334) to restrict out-of-state and international travel by the senate president, members, and staff. several other bills were also discussed and advanced.

**key actions**
- **sr 334**: amends senate rules to prohibit the senate president and members from traveling outside the u.s. or outside georgia (in their final 6 months of office) at senate expense. also prohibits senate staff from traveling internationally at senate expense.

**bills introduced (first reading)**

title: Capitol Report Day 25 02/28/25
text:
capitol report day 25 02/28/25 # georgia capitol report day 25 - 02/28/25

## overview
this session saw the passage of a bill to expand the georgia promise scholarship to the biological and adopted children of fostering families, a move aimed at incentivizing foster care. the house also passed a bill to modernize the state's 911 call center system. additionally, senate republicans filed legislation to further investigate the new georgia project and its founder stacey abrams over alleged financial misconduct, despite a previous investigation by the state ethics commission.

## key actions
**hb 423**: bill to implement geographic information systems in 911 call centers to improve emergency response times.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills detected.

## notable moments
- debate over the foster care scholarship bill, with democrats objecting over concerns about potential misuse of funds and the lack of a similar scholarship for foster children themselves.
- senate republicans filing legislation to further investigate the new georgia project and stacey abrams, despite a previous investigation by the state ethics commission.

## votes
- the foster care scholarship bill passed 32-22 along party lines.

## attendance
a quorum was present for the legislative proceedings.

## adjournment
the legislature adjourned and will reconvene on monday for day 26, leading up to cross-over day on thursday. the senate debated a bill that would allow the biological and adopted children of fostering
families to access the $6,500 georgia promise scholarship.
this is an important step to ensure that those people that take care of the most vulnerable
in our population have an initial incentive to do so.
democrats objected because of the threat to families misusing the funds, as well as
we are not giving that same scholarship to the very foster children they will have in
their households.
bill passed 32 to 22 along party lines. across the hall, the house passed a bill that would
modernize the state's 911 call center system. house bill 423 would implement geographic information
systems to more accurately locate the caller and reduce emergency response times.
whether it be folks in rural georgia, suburban georgia, or in our urban centers, all across
our state, we see a great need to utilize current technology.
also today, senate republicans filed legislation to investigate the new georgia project, and
its founder, stacey abrams, for alleged financial misconduct.
the state ethics commission already investigated and levied a large fine on the organization.
but lieutenant governor bert jones says that more scrutiny is needed.
democrats say it's a waste of time.
lawmakers return on monday for day 26, as the lead up to cross-over day on thursday continues.
for gbb news, i'm sarah callis at the state capitol.

title: Ban on transgender athletes playing in girls' sports passes in Georgia House
text:
ban on transgender athletes playing in girls' sports passes in georgia house ## overview

the georgia house session discussed and passed sb1, a bill that bans transgender athletes from participating in girls' sports in the state. the debate featured input from both supporters and opponents of the legislation.

## key actions

**sb1**: ban on transgender athletes playing in girls' sports in georgia

## bills introduced (first reading)

none noted.

## notable moments

- clergy and parents of transgender children spoke against sb1 during the debate.
- supporters argued the bill would ensure a "level playing field" for female athletes.
- it was noted that there are currently zero transgender students competing in k-12 sports in georgia.

## votes

no recorded votes detected.

## attendance

quorum was present for the discussion.

## adjournment

the timing of adjournment and next session date were not provided. all we're looking for is simply a level playing field,

not a single coach, not a single athletic organization,

in k through 12 sports in georgia, zero.

title: 3/21/23 - Senate Committee on Appropriations
text:
3/21/23 - senate committee on appropriations overview:
- the senate appropriations committee considered several key bills, including hb 611 and the fy 2024 budget bill (hb 19).
- there was notable discussion around preserving the general assembly's role in appropriating settlement funds and addressing issues in the state's medicaid, child welfare, and mental health systems.

key actions:
- **hb 611**: requires that any settlement agreement or proceeds from a settlement agreement be appropriated by the general assembly after june 1, 2023.
- **hb 19**: the senate appropriations committee substitute for the fy 2024 budget bill. key provisions include:
  - restoring medicaid utilization cost cuts
  - shoring up the state health benefit plan by $1 billion
  - addressing structural deficits at child care institutions
  - increasing reimbursement rates for the "babies can't wait" early intervention program
  - providing over $40 million to address mental health staffing and facility needs
  - funding 500 new comp waivers
  - fully funding dyslexia screening for k-3 students a year earlier than required by sb 48

- none mentioned

# georgia house - day 2 (2026-11-04) session highlights

the session focused on the importance of leaders taking time for personal reflection and prayer, especially during times of cultural and political divisions. there was no substantive legislative action detected.

- rep. can trail introduced guest chaplain matt lawson, who spoke about the need for leaders to "watch over their own souls" through prayer and reflection.

a quorum was present, with members being instructed to vote green to signify their attendance.

## adjournment
the session was recessed until 10:30 am to allow members time to get covid-19 tests, after which the day's business would commence. you

- rep. wilkerson spoke in support of sb 144, stating it was about ensuring local control over housing authority operations.

georgia house - day 40 (2026-03-29) here is a summary of the key points from the georgia house session transcript:

**overview**
the session focused on several bills, including sb 233 related to promise scholarship accounts, hb 80 regarding the uniform unsworn declaration act, and sb 63 on bail and bond. there was some procedural wrangling, including a motion to recommit sb 233 back to the rules committee.

**key actions**
- **sb 233**: bill to establish promise scholarship accounts funded by the state at $6,000 per year. removed from the table but then recommitted to the rules committee.
- **hb 80**: bill to enact the uniform unsworn declaration act, allowing written declarations without notarization to be introduced as evidence. house agreed to senate substitute.
- **sb 63**: bill to amend laws related to bail and bonds. house insisted on its position.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
no new bills were introduced during this session.

**notable moments**
- debate and vote on motion to remove sb 233 from the table and then recommit it to rules committee.
- explanation of changes made to hb 80 in the senate substitute.
- discussion of house insisting on its position for sb 63 related to bail and bonds.

**votes**
- motion to remove sb 233 from table: 90-74, passed.
- motion to recommit sb 233 to rules: 97-73, passed.
- motion for house to agree to senate substitute for hb 80: 172-0, passed.
- motion for house to insist on its position for sb 63: no objection, passed.

**attendance**
quorum was present, as indicated by the votes.

**adjournment**
the house stood in recess until 3:05 pm.

## overview
the session focused on passing a bill to add the word "courage" to the pledge of allegiance to the georgia state flag, as well as a bill to provide relief for victims of human trafficking who were convicted of crimes as a result of being trafficked.

## key actions
**sb 152**: adds the word "courage" to the pledge of allegiance to the georgia state flag.  
**sb 565**: allows victims of human trafficking to petition to have their sentences vacated if the crimes were committed as a direct result of being trafficked.

none detected.

- there was some discussion around whether adding "courage" to the pledge would require changes to the state seal, which the representative clarified would not be necessary.
- the house voted to pass sb 152 by a vote of 125-23.
- representative hagen presented sb 565, which aims to provide relief for victims of human trafficking who were convicted of crimes as a result of being trafficked.

## votes
**sb 152**: passed 125-23

## attendance
no quorum issues noted.

georgia house - day 28 (2026-03-06) overview:
the georgia house session on 2026-03-06 featured debate and passage of several bills, including legislation related to professional licensing reforms and tracking foreign funding at state universities.

key actions:
**hb 579**: provides reforms to the state's professional licensing system, including giving the licensing division more authority and allowing boards to focus on disciplining bad actors.
**hb 549**: extends the window for law enforcement agencies to seek reimbursement for training expenses when an officer leaves for another agency, from 15 months to 36 months.
**hb 150**: requires the university system of georgia to report quarterly on any funding received from "foreign countries of concern" beyond standard tuition payments.

no new bills were introduced during this session.

- rep. fleming presented hb 150, which aims to increase transparency around foreign funding at state universities. there was some debate around the scope of the reporting requirements.

- hb 579 passed 158-2.
- hb 549 passed 164-0.

georgia house - day 22 (2026-03-02) here is a summary of the georgia house session from 2026-03-02:

**overview**
this session focused on substantive legislation, including a bill to combat human trafficking and another to allow certain medical professionals to incorporate as a professional corporation.

**key actions**
**hb 823**: requires the georgia department of driver services to permanently revoke the commercial driver's license (cdl) of an individual convicted of using a commercial motor vehicle to commit the offense of trafficking a person for labor or sexual servitude.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- hb 816: allows chiropractors and medical doctors to incorporate as a professional corporation when practicing together.
- hb 578: authorizes the department of human services and its contractors to receive conviction data on volunteers, students, and interns to ensure they pass criminal background checks.

- representative houston gaines presented hb 823, noting georgia's high rates of child sex trafficking and the need for additional tools to fight this issue.
- representatives expressed bipartisan support for hb 823 and the efforts of first lady marty kemp to combat human trafficking.
- there was discussion of a recent incident in columbus where truck drivers helped rescue a young trafficking victim.

**votes**
- hb 823 passed with a vote of 166-0.
- hb 578 passed with a vote of 166-0.

a quorum was present, and no issues with attendance were noted.

the session focused on house bill 1125, which would phase out the use of subminimum wage certificates for workers with disabilities in georgia. the bill aims to send a message that the state values the contributions of people with disabilities and believes they should be paid at least minimum wage.

**key actions**
- **hb 1125**: phases out the use of federal 14(c) certificates that allow employers to pay subminimum wages to workers with disabilities.

**bills introduced (first reading)**

- rep. cooper highlighted her legislative intern leah, who uses a wheelchair, as an example of a highly capable employee with a disability.
- several representatives, including reps. parsons, sebaugh, and carpenter, expressed support for the bill and the idea of paying workers with disabilities at least minimum wage.

title: Georgia House - Day 27 (2026-02-27)
text:
georgia house - day 27 (2026-02-27) here is a summary of the key points from the georgia house session transcript:

**overview:**
the session featured the consideration and passage of several notable bills, including legislation to move the state tax appeals process to the judicial branch and a bill regulating amateur combat sports organizations.

**key actions:**
- **hb 1267:** enabling legislation to move the state tax appeals process from the superior court system to a new tax tribunal in the judicial branch.
- **hr 598:** constitutional amendment to authorize the creation of a state tax tribunal.
- **hb 598:** requires licensing and regulation of certain amateur combat sports organizations by the georgia athletic and entertainment commission.
- **hb 1115:** revises the maximum allowable sales and use tax rate.

**bills introduced (first reading):** none mentioned.

**notable moments:**
- debate and passage of hb 1267 to move the state tax appeals process.
- presentation and adoption of hr 598 to amend the constitution to enable the tax tribunal.
- debate and passage of hb 598 to regulate amateur combat sports organizations.

**votes:**
- hb 1267 passed 161-0.
- hr 598 passed 165-0. 
- hb 598 passed 164-1.
- hb 1115 passed, but the vote count was not provided.

**attendance:** no specific quorum notes.

**adjournment:** transcript does not indicate when the session adjourned or the date of the next scheduled session.

## overview
this session featured the passage of several bills, including sb 387 and sb 386 related to redistricting for the maryweather county board of education and county commission. there was also discussion around sb 457 regarding the consolidation of richmond county and the city of augusta.

**sb 387**: bill to reconstitute the maryweather county board of education districts, passed 142-5.
**sb 386**: bill to amend the act creating the maryweather county board of commissioners, passed 142-7.
**sb 457**: bill to amend the act providing for the consolidation of richmond county and the city of augusta, under committee consideration.

**overview**:
this session focused on several key pieces of legislation, including bills related to solar power financing, increased penalties for cruelty to children, and updates to insurance and fire safety regulations.

**key actions**:
- **hb 300**: provided protections for landowners entering into solar power facility agreements and maintained the balance of solar energy integration in the state's power mix.
- **hb 1022**: the "colton mcneal act" increased penalties for first and second-degree cruelty to children, especially involving disabled minors.
- **hb 984**: updated practices of the department of insurance and office of the safety fire commissioner.

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
no new bills were introduced during this session.

**notable moments**:
- representative trade kelly presented hb 300 and worked with the agriculture and consumer affairs committee to avoid referring to solar facilities as "farms".
- representative sainz presented hb 1022, the "colton mcneal act", to increase penalties for cruelty to children cases, which were described as some of the most difficult to prosecute.
- representative lumston presented hb 984 to update insurance and fire safety regulations.

**votes**:
- hb 300 passed 146-0.
- hb 1022 passed 158-0.
- no other recorded votes mentioned.

**attendance**:
no quorum issues were noted.

**adjournment**:
the session adjourned without a specific next meeting date provided. you

title: Georgia House - Day 2 (2026-01-12)

georgia house - day 2 (2026-01-12) ## georgia house of representatives - day 2, 2022 session (january 12, 2022)

### overview
second day of the 2022 session, the morning after georgia bulldogs' national championship victory. session opened with championship game highlights played in the chamber.

### key actions
- **sr 362**: joint resolution notifying governor that general assembly has convened (adopted)
- committee of notification appointed (8 members including rep. meeks, rep. bonner, chairman hogan)

### bills introduced (first reading)
- **hb 870-874**: local bills for bullock county board of commissioners, bullock county board of education, bibb county redistricting

### morning orders & memorials
- **officer ricky tottenson**: moment of silence for newton police department officer (18-year veteran, school resource officer known as "officer t") who died in the line of duty
- coweta delegation presented the memorial

### announcements
- **local redistricting**: chairman tankersley reminded members about january 7th memo on local redistricting procedures; bills affecting 2022 elections should pass by first week of february
- **senator cleveland memorial**: originally scheduled for friday, postponed to april
- **keep georgia wild day**: scheduled for january 13th in the rotunda at 9 am with governor and conservation groups
- **state of the state**: governor's address scheduled for thursday, january 13th

### notable moments
- championship game celebration video played at session opening
- speaker joked about rep. gullet attending a different bowl game (and losing)
- birthday recognition: chairman jan tankersley

### adjournment
adjourned until thursday, january 13th at 10 am (state of the state day). you

georgia house - day 1 (2026-01-10) ## georgia house of representatives - day 1, 2022 session (january 10, 2022)

### overview
opening day of the 2022 legislative session, notable for coinciding with the georgia bulldogs' national championship football game.

### key actions
- **hr 568**: notified senate that house has convened
- **hr 569**: called joint session for governor's address (scheduled for thursday at 10:45 am)
- **hr 570**: established session schedule - out tuesday (jan 11), reconvene wednesday at 11 am, thursday/friday at 10 am, then budget hearing recess

### bills introduced (first reading)
- **hb 843**: property tax exemptions amendment
- **hb 846-849**: traffic/road safety and child abuse reporting
- **hb 850**: holiday observances
- **hb 851-853**: inmate policies and detention conditions
- **hb 854**: incorporation of city of buckhead
- **hr 529**: national park services concerns

### notable moments
- rep. west cantrell (term-limited after 8 years) delivered scripture reading from romans 12
- multiple references to georgia bulldogs championship game that evening
- birthday recognitions: rep. karen bennett, rep. betsy holland, rep. beth camp, rep. wiltson, rep. derek jackson

### attendance
full session, journal confirmed without objection.

### adjournment
adjourned until wednesday, january 12th at 11 am to accommodate championship celebrations. you

title: Lawmakers Day 28 2025
text:
lawmakers day 28 2025 overview:
the georgia legislature had a busy 28th day session, with a number of notable bills being passed or introduced. the session was marked by a bipartisan approach on some school safety measures, while more partisan debates emerged around a proposed income tax cut and a bill seeking to limit local firearm regulations.

key actions:
**sb 17**: mandates mobile alert panic systems for schools and requires mapping of school properties to aid emergency response.
**sb 61**: adds new charges that students could be prosecuted for in superior court, including terroristic threats.
**sb 179**: requires sharing of student disciplinary history when transferring schools and holds parents legally responsible for not disclosing suspensions.
**sb 163**: rescinds local city and county laws over guns and weapons, entrusting regulation exclusively to the state.
**hb 111**: reduces the state's flat income tax rate from 5.39% to 5.19%.
**hb 112**: provides a one-time tax rebate of $250 for single taxpayers and $500 for married couples.
**hb 657**: annexes 45 small parcels of land into the newly formed city of mulberry.

bills introduced (first reading):
no new bills were introduced during this session.

notable moments:
- senator colton moore's impassioned speech advocating for his bill sb 163 to rescind local firearm regulations.
- debate between republicans and democrats over the merits of the income tax cut bill hb 111.

votes:
- sb 17, sb 179 passed unanimously.
- sb 61 passed 33-22 along party lines.
- sb 163 passed 33-23 along party lines. 
- hb 111 passed 110-60, mostly along party lines.
- hb 112 passed unanimously.
- hb 657 passed 98-76, mostly along party lines.

attendance:
the session maintained a quorum throughout the proceedings.

adjournment:
the legislature adjourned for the day. the next session date was not specified. you are looking at a live view from under the gold dome where this house is working hard
on the 28th day of the legislative session.

title: Sen. Tillery Press Conference on Eliminating State Income Tax | 07-24-2025
text:
sen. tillery press conference on eliminating state income tax | 07-24-2025 ## overview
sen. tillery announced his plan to introduce legislation in the 2026 legislative session to eliminate the georgia state income tax. he will chair a study committee to determine how to responsibly achieve this goal while protecting the state's priorities. the senator emphasized this is not a debate about whether to eliminate the tax, but rather how to do it.

## key actions
none detected

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected

## notable moments
- sen. tillery stated his commitment to eliminating the georgia state income tax during the 2026 legislative session.
- he will chair a study committee to determine the path forward, working closely with the lieutenant governor.
- the senator argued that eliminating the state income tax is about competitiveness, economic freedom, and allowing georgians to keep more of their money.
- he pointed to 9 states that have already eliminated their state income tax as examples georgia can learn from.

## votes
none detected

## attendance
no quorum notes provided.

## adjournment
no adjournment details provided. well, thank you all first of all for being here today. i appreciate that.
in the 2026 legislative session, i will introduce legislation to take the georgia state income tax rate to zero.
let me repeat that for you one time. during the georgia 2026 legislative session, i will introduce legislation to take georgia's income tax rate to zero.
this may not happen overnight, but i'm committed to delivering on this goal in a way that protects
our state's core priorities, health care, education, infrastructure and public safety.
my mission is simple, eliminate georgia's income tax and its entirety.
and over the next several months, i will chair study committees, work closely with my
colleagues, and of course consult with lieutenant governor bert jones to chart a realistic
and responsible path to eliminate georgia's income tax.
let me be clear, my role as chair is not to debate whether we do
away with the state income tax, it's to determine how we will do
away with the state income tax.
georgia's state income tax was started roughly 80 years ago
during the great depression, and for a large part of that time,
it remained at 6% largely unquestioned.
it's only been in the past decade under republican leadership
that we've seen that percentage rate finally begin to trickle down.
and while that's progress, it's just a start.
because we don't operate in a vacuum, you see our neighboring states like north carolina
and south carolina are quickly working to reduce their state income tax.
and nine states in our nation have already completely done away with theirs.
and these aren't just red states and they're not just blue states.
you've got wyoming, washington, new hampshire, texas, tennessee, and of course florida.
and when folks mention florida, the first thing they do is say, well, that's because of
tourism, but tourism doesn't explain how tennessee did it.
and it doesn't explain how new hampshire did it.

title: Sen. H Jones Dem Caucus Press Conference on Torte Reform  | 02/20/2025
text:
sen. h jones dem caucus press conference on torte reform  | 02/20/2025 ## overview
this press conference by georgia state senate democratic caucus leader h. jones focuses on the introduction of sb 223, the "pro-people pro-business act," which aims to reform tort liability laws in the state. the bill seeks to balance the interests of protecting public safety and shielding businesses from frivolous lawsuits.

## key actions
**sb 223**: the "pro-people pro-business act" that introduces several provisions to reform premises liability laws, including:
- establishing an affirmative defense for businesses located in high-crime areas
- creating a rebuttable presumption against liability if businesses have taken safety measures like proper lighting and security

## bills introduced (first reading)
- sb 223: the "pro-people pro-business act" on tort reform

## overview
the session focused on the discussion and presentation of senate bill 125, which aims to decouple the sequential order of the internship hours and the professional engineering (pe) exam for engineers in georgia. the bill also includes provisions from house bill 34 and house bill 187 to address licensing issues and streamline regulations for various contractor professions.

## key actions
**sb 125**: amends the code related to professional engineers and land surveyors to decouple the sequential order of internship hours and the pe exam, allowing engineers to take the exam after earning their degree while still requiring the 4-year internship before becoming licensed.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced during this portion of the session.

- representative lauren mcdonald presented sb 125 and explained the rationale behind the bill, noting it would provide flexibility for engineers without compromising professional requirements.

- the co-chair of the blue ribbon committee that worked on these licensing issues spoke in support of the legislation.
- representative gabe mccoy, a registered engineer, expressed concerns about the bill potentially allowing unqualified people to become licensed engineers.

this session focused on finalizing the state's fiscal year 2025 budget, with a significant portion dedicated to hurricane relief efforts and support for the department of corrections. substantive legislation was passed, including appropriation bills and funding for various state agencies and programs.

**hb 67**: amended state budget for fiscal year 2025, including $862 million in hurricane relief and $345 million for the department of corrections.

02/25/2025 senate committee on regulated industries & utilities here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senate committee on regulated industries & utilities session on 02/25/2025:

## overview
the session focused on senate bill 34, which aims to ensure that the costs of electricity incurred by data centers are paid for by the data centers themselves rather than being passed on to residential and small business customers. there was discussion around past practices of customers subsidizing the costs of large users like data centers, and whether the recent public service commission (psc) rulings adequately addressed this issue.

## key actions
**sb 34**: requires that the costs of electricity incurred by data centers be paid for by the data centers, not residential and small business customers.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none.

## notable moments
- senator huffstettler presented the changes made to the committee substitute of sb 34, noting it aimed to codify that data center electricity costs should not be borne by residential and small business ratepayers.
- there was discussion around past practices of customers subsidizing large users like data centers, and whether the recent psc rulings adequately addressed this issue.
- senator lucas questioned whether the data center electricity costs were actually appearing on customer utility bills.

## votes
none recorded.

## attendance
quorum was present, with some committee members noted as attending a veterans affairs meeting.

## adjournment

## overview
the session focused on insurance-related legislation, with the senate considering amendments to house bill 348 regarding captive insurance companies. there was some debate around proposed amendments that aimed to restrict insurance companies from easily leaving the state.

## key actions
**hb 348**: bill to amend the georgia code to expand the lines of insurance and reinsurance that limited-purpose subsidiary and captive insurance companies can engage in.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none mentioned in the transcript.

## notable moments
- senator from the 20th spoke in favor of hb 348, arguing it would modernize georgia's captive insurance laws.
- senator from the 2nd introduced two amendments to hb 348:
    - amendment 1 would prohibit insurance companies from leaving georgia if they made a profit in at least 4 of the previous 5 years.
    - amendment 2 would prohibit insurers from transferring funds between affiliates with intent to mislead regarding profitability.
- the senator from the 20th spoke against both amendments, arguing they were anti-free enterprise and would restrict insurers' ability to manage their finances.

title: 2-27-2025 | GLBC Priorities Press Conference
text:
2-27-2025 | glbc priorities press conference overview:
the georgia legislative black caucus held a press conference to outline their legislative priorities for the 2025-2026 session. the priorities focused on expanding healthcare access, affordable housing, supporting black-owned businesses, ensuring equitable education, criminal justice reform, and protecting voting rights and black cultural heritage.

key actions:
**sb 50**: peach care plus act of 2025 to expand medicaid under the affordable care act
**hb 149**: health mothers act to address high maternal mortality rates, especially among black women
**sb 65**: mandates kindergarten before 1st grade
**sb 54**: establishes statewide database to track school safety threats
**hb 135**: prohibits housing discrimination based on hairstyles associated with race or ethnicity
**hb a**: renews state investment tax credit and removes barriers for investors

bills introduced (first reading):
- legislation to define housing habitability standards based on federal definitions
- restrictions on corporations buying up homes in georgia

notable moments:
- chair nikki merritt outlined the glbc's key priorities across healthcare, housing, economic empowerment, education, public safety, and advocacy.
- whip terry cummings and vice chair doreen carter provided additional details on the legislative agenda.
- references were made to the trump administration's education reforms and the new conservative white house administration's proposed cuts to arts/culture funding.

votes: 
no specific votes mentioned, but several bills were described as passed or in committee.

attendance:
no quorum notes provided.

adjournment:
no adjournment time given, but this appears to be an ongoing press conference. good afternoon, everyone. we're going to go ahead and get started.
thank you all for joining this afternoon. my name is senator nikki merritt,
and i have the pleasure of serving as chair of the georgia legislative black caucus.
and i'm very happy to share our 2025, 2026 priorities. as you guys know, we're in the
the biennial so it's every two years so this would carry us for the next two years.
so whatever we don't have of our priorities that we don't get completed this year, we
will continue that work next year.
and at the georgia legislative black caucus, we remain committed to policies that uplift
black communities across the state.
we're fighting to expand health care access.
that is just one of our priorities, pushing for full medicaid expansion, enhanced maternal
health programs and increased community-based mental health services. in the area of housing,
we are advocating for incentivizing affordable options, instituting, rent stabilization,
and strengthening tenant protections. on the economic front, our agenda supports black-owned
businesses through tax incentives, grants, and low interest loans, improving workers' rights,
and financial education programs. for education, our next priority, we demand equitable,
k through 12 funding, increased support for our hbcus, expanded scholarships, and a statewide
inclusion of black history, curriculum, and public safety and justice, our next priority.
we are calling for reforms. we call for trust-based policing, comprehensive background checks,
and accountability measures to protect black communities.

expanding and protecting voting rights,

for the arts and community spaces.

title: House Evening Session for Day 38 of the 2025 Legislative Session
text:
house evening session for day 38 of the 2025 legislative session here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia house evening session for day 38 of the 2025 legislative session:

## overview
the house session focused on passing key school safety legislation, including provisions from previous bills sb 17 (known as ricky and alyssa's law) and incorporating new requirements around emergency communications, threat assessment plans, and mental health support for students. the session also included the introduction and passage of sb 199 related to campaign finance and transparency.

## key actions
**hb 268**: amends education laws to require public schools to implement mobile panic alert systems, share digital mapping data with emergency responders, establish threat assessment plans, and create a student advocacy specialist position to coordinate mental health services.

**sb 199**: requires the state ethics commission to not accept or reject complaints against candidates within 60 days of an election, and streamlines campaign finance reporting requirements.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none noted in the transcript.

## notable moments
- rep. persinger provided an overview of the changes made to hb 268 in the senate substitute, highlighting the incorporation of ricky and alyssa's law and new requirements around emergency communications, threat assessments, and mental health support.
- several representatives asked clarifying questions about the implementation and funding of the new school safety requirements in hb 268.
- there was discussion about ensuring timely transfer of student disciplinary records between schools.

## votes
- the house voted 154-12 to agree to the senate's substitute for hb 268, passing the school safety legislation.

## attendance
no explicit quorum notes provided.

## adjournment
the transcript does not provide information about the time of adjournment or the date of the next session. 268 as amended by the senate, and we will agree to accept to as amended by the senate.

text:
house pm meeting for day 36 of the 2025 session overview:
the georgia house session covered substantive legislation related to the state's behavioral health reform and innovation commission. key changes included expanding the commission's membership to better represent those with lived experiences of mental health and addiction issues.

key actions:
**sb 233**: amends the law regarding the behavioral health reform and innovation commission to increase its membership from 24 to 30 members, specifically adding representatives who have personal or family experience with mental health or addiction challenges.

bills introduced (first reading):
none noted in the transcript.

- rep. cannon expressed support for the bill, noting the importance of including the perspectives of those who have navigated behavioral health challenges firsthand. 
- rep. oliver provided historical context, explaining how the commission was established in a bipartisan manner under former speaker ralston and has made significant progress on mental health funding and reforms.

votes:
no recorded votes mentioned, but the bill appears to have passed without objection.

attendance:
no quorum issues noted.

title: Senate PM Day 40 of the 2025 Legislative Session
text:
senate pm day 40 of the 2025 legislative session here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senate pm day 40 of the 2025 legislative session:

## overview
the session included discussions on several bills, including hb 172 related to student loan forgiveness for veterinarians, hb 222 regarding bond information requirements, and amendments to other bills. there was some debate and procedural wrangling, but ultimately several bills were passed.

## key actions
**hb 172**: provides for limits on student loan forgiveness program for veterinary education and other purposes.  
**hb 222**: amends title 17 to revise certain bond holding requirements and require inclusion of contact information.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced during this session.

## notable moments
- there was a discussion about the need for large animal veterinarians in georgia, with a senator recounting a presentation he attended by an alabama veterinarian.
- an amendment was proposed to hb 222 to revise bond holding requirements, but a point of order was raised that it was a "floor substitute" and should be struck per the senate rules.

## votes
- hb 172 passed with a vote of 43-4.
- the amendment to hb 222 was subject to a point of order challenging it as a "floor substitute".

## attendance
a quorum was present, with one senator excused for business outside the chamber.

## adjournment

title: House PM 2 Meeting for Day 40 of the 2025 Session
text:
house pm 2 meeting for day 40 of the 2025 session overview:
- the georgia house held a legislative session on day 40 of the 2025 session. the session focused on passing two bills related to the judicial system and public records.

key actions:
- **sb 218**: moves the prosecuting attorney's qualifications commission (paqc) from the prosecuting attorney's council to the administrative office of the courts, clarifies the appeals process, and modifies confidentiality related to district attorneys and solicitor generals.
- **sb 12**: defines the custodian of public records and specifies that requests to view public records must go through the custodian. also requires third parties with government records to provide them to the custodian upon request.

bills introduced (first reading): none detected

notable moments:
- debate on whether sb 218 removed a requirement for sheriff's deputies in courthouses.
- confirmation that sb 12 reverted back to the original senate-passed version with carefully vetted language.

votes:
- sb 218 passed 149-18.
- sb 12 passed 167-1.

attendance: quorum present, no notes on attendance.

text:

**overview**:
the press conference focused on governor kemp's education and school safety initiatives, highlighting significant investments and legislative actions taken to support public schools, teachers, and student security in georgia.

none detected.

**bills introduced (first reading)**: 
none detected.

- kemp announced an additional $10.3 million for local school districts to support pupil transportation.
- since taking office, kemp stated that over $185 million in one-time school security grants (roughly $80,000 per school) have been provided.
- kemp proposed an additional $50 million in one-time school security grants for the current fiscal year, bringing the total to over $86,000 per school.
- lieutenant governor jones and speaker burns expressed strong bipartisan support for the school safety initiatives and a commitment to continue building on these efforts.

title: Safe Gun Storage Press Conference   1-28-2025
text:
safe gun storage press conference   1-28-2025 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia safe gun storage press conference on 1-28-2025:

## overview
the press conference focused on legislative efforts to address safe gun storage and reduce unintentional gun deaths of children in georgia. key speakers highlighted the state's high rates of unintentional shootings by children and called for action this legislative session.

## key actions
**bill 1**: creation of a statewide database to identify students in need of essential services related to gun safety
**bill 2**: establishment of a statewide "zarc" (gun safety and responsibility coordinator) position to disseminate information, work with industry, and advise the legislature

## bills introduced (first reading)
- safe storage law with misdemeanor penalty for knowingly allowing minors to access firearms
- legislation to keep individuals adjudicated as dangers to themselves or others in the federal background check system

## notable moments
- speakers emphasized that hardening schools alone is insufficient to prevent tragedies, and that addressing easy access to guns in communities is crucial.
- bipartisan support was highlighted, with speakers from both parties calling for action.
- the fallout from the recent mass shooting at appalachia high school was discussed as driving the urgency for legislative solutions.

## votes
no votes were mentioned.

## attendance

title: Senator Hickman | Disability and Employment Press Conference | 1/29/2025
text:
senator hickman | disability and employment press conference | 1/29/2025 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senator hickman | disability and employment press conference | 1/29/2025 session:

**overview:**
the session focused on the dignity and pay act, a bill introduced by senator billy hickman to end the use of sub-minimum wages for workers with disabilities in georgia by 2027. the session featured speeches by advocates highlighting the unfair practice of paying some georgians with disabilities less than minimum wage.

**key actions:**
**hb 1125**: the dignity and pay act, introduced by senator hickman, aims to phase out the use of sub-minimum wages for workers with disabilities in georgia by 2027.

**bills introduced (first reading):** 
none detected.

**notable moments:**
- executive director of the georgia council on developmental disabilities, darcy robb, spoke about the current law that allows some disability service providers to pay workers with disabilities less than minimum wage, with documented cases of wages as low as $0.22/hour.
- advocates, including the sister of a worker with a disability, shared personal stories about the impacts of sub-minimum wages and the capabilities of workers with disabilities when given the opportunity.
- senator hickman introduced the dignity and pay act, explaining that the current law sends the wrong message about the value of contributions from people with disabilities, and that fair wages are possible as evidenced by georgia's "georgia as a model employer" law.

**votes:**

quorum present, with over 200 advocates in attendance.

title: 02/28/2025 Sen.Merritt Press Conference on Family, and Workforce Justice
text:
02/28/2025 sen.merritt press conference on family, and workforce justice overview:
senator nikki marrett held a press conference to introduce her "family and workforce justice" legislative agenda for the 2025 session. the package includes several bills aimed at addressing threats to civil rights, protecting vulnerable populations, and ensuring affordable housing options.

key actions:
**sb 92**: "red flag law" to temporarily remove firearms from those deemed a threat to themselves or others
**sb 164**: bans surveillance-based pricing, wage discrimination, and other unfair data-driven practices by corporations

**sb 166**: holds corporate landlords accountable for providing safe and high-quality housing
**sb 167**: prohibits discrimination in ai-based decision-making systems

- sb 92 - "red flag law"
- sb 164 - ban on surveillance-based pricing, wage discrimination
- sb 165 - protections for children on social media 
- sb 166 - accountability for corporate landlords
- sb 167 - prohibiting ai-based discrimination

- senator marrett called for bipartisan support on the legislation, stating "these solutions are not about red or blue"
- she criticized the lack of hearings so far on democratic bills in the 2025 session

03/05/2025 sen.h.jones ii  press conference w/ aclu and naacp on dei here is a summary of the georgia 03/05/2025 sen. h.jones ii press conference with the aclu and naacp on the dei session:

**overview**
the press conference addressed the recent passage of senate bill 120 in the georgia senate, which bans promoting, supporting or maintaining any programs or activities that advocate for diversity, equity and inclusion (dei) at post-secondary institutions. speakers strongly criticized the bill, arguing it is an assault on american and georgia values of inclusion and diversity.

**sb 120**: bill banning dei programs and activities at post-secondary institutions in georgia

none mentioned

- sen. nikki merritt called sb 120 a "tone-deaf legislative tragedy" that rejects georgia's legacy of diversity and the civil rights movement.
- former rep. roger bruce questioned why lawmakers need laws dealing with diversity to help descendants of slavery, arguing the "playing field is not level" due to past injustices.
- nancy flake johnson, president of the urban league of greater atlanta, said sb 120 limits constitutional rights and that dei is one of the best strategies to bring people together and achieve parity.

none recorded

no specific quorum notes

title: 3/12/2025--GLBC--Press Conference on SB67
text:
3/12/2025--glbc--press conference on sb67 overview:
- this press conference focused on opposition to sb 68, a bill that georgia legislators argue would unfairly limit victims' ability to seek justice in court, particularly for survivors of sex trafficking and drunk driving accidents.

key actions:
- **sb 68**: bill that would restrict victims' ability to sue businesses, which legislators argue would protect corporate interests over victims' rights.

bills introduced (first reading):
- none mentioned

notable moments:
- emotional testimony from sex trafficking survivors recounting their "repeated rape, repeated sadimization, repeated beatings, repeated torture and torment at the hands of abusers."
- legislators argue the bill is "poorly drafted" and proponents could not articulate a scenario where sex trafficking victims could seek justice under the bill.
- legislators call on the governor and republican leadership to work with them to improve the bill to better balance business and victim interests.
- accusations that the governor and republican leadership have targeted and tried to silence victim advocacy groups like mothers against drunk driving who oppose the bill.

votes: 
- none mentioned

attendance:
- no quorum notes

title: Sen. Jackson | Equal Opportunity for Women's Sports Press Conference | 02 - 03 - 2025
text:
sen. jackson | equal opportunity for women's sports press conference | 02 - 03 - 2025 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia sen. jackson | equal opportunity for women's sports press conference | 02 - 03 - 2025 session:

## overview
the press conference focused on addressing the inequities faced by girls and women in sports in georgia, even decades after the enactment of title ix. the speakers discussed various issues such as unequal treatment, lack of resources and funding, and media attention for girls' sports teams. the main legislative focus was on sb 41, the "equal opportunities in girl sports act", which aims to address these disparities.

## key actions
- **sb 41**: the "equal opportunities in girl sports act" introduced to address inequities faced by girls' sports teams in georgia.
- **sb 1**: the "fair and safe athletic opportunities act" introduced by senate republicans, seen as a "bully tactic" targeting the trans community.

## bills introduced (first reading)
- sb 41: the "equal opportunities in girl sports act"
- sb 1: the "fair and safe athletic opportunities act"

## notable moments
- speeches by sen. jackson, rep. oliver, and a female sports advocate highlighting the ongoing challenges and inequities in girls' and women's sports in georgia.
- calls to address real issues facing girls' sports teams, such as lack of resources, funding, and media coverage, rather than focusing on the "non-existence of girl trans athletes".
- celebration of progress made, such as the inclusion of women on the georgia high school sports association board, and the addition of fast-pitch softball to the high school sports system.

## votes
no recorded votes mentioned, but sb 41 and sb 1 were said to be making their way through the legislative process.

## attendance
no specific quorum notes provided.

## adjournment

title: Democrats Press Conference on SR 84 02/05/2025
text:
democrats press conference on sr 84 02/05/2025 # georgia senate session summary - 02/05/2025

## overview
this session featured a press conference by georgia senate democrats in support of senate resolution 84 (sr 84), which would amend the state constitution to protect abortion access up to fetal viability. the democrats argued that this would give georgia voters a direct say on the issue, contrary to the state's current restrictions.

## key actions
**sr 84**: constitutional amendment to protect abortion access up to fetal viability

## bills introduced (first reading)
none noted

## notable moments
- senate democratic leader jones expressed the party's support for sr 84 and senator harrell's leadership on the issue.
- senator harrell explained that the resolution would allow georgia voters to have a direct say on abortion rights, unlike the current situation where legislators can ignore public opinion due to gerrymandering.
- harrell cited examples of harm caused by georgia's restrictive abortion law, including the deaths of two women due to delayed care.
- harrell argued that the people of georgia deserve the same opportunity as voters in other states to directly decide on abortion access.

## votes
sr 84 passed

## attendance
quorum present

## adjournment

democrats unlike republicans truly mean it when we talk about individual freedom. and this is
indicative today of our support of sr 84, which will allow women the right to choose the reproductive
health options. and we believe the people of georgia also view women as equal citizens and will
will support her health care options by going to the ballot box and supporting sr-84.
we as the democratic caucus support sr-84 and especially support senator harrell as
should be spearheading these efforts.
so with that, i will give the podium to senator harrell.
thank you, leader jones, and thank you all for coming today.

that's why we are fighting for sr-84, a constitutional amendment that would protect abortion access

title: 4/3/2025 | Democratic Caucus Press Conference on HB127
text:
4/3/2025 | democratic caucus press conference on hb127 here is a summary of the key points from the georgia legislative session transcript on the democratic caucus press conference regarding hb 127:

**overview**:
the democratic caucus strongly opposed hb 127, describing it as a bill that would take georgia "backwards" on issues of race, discrimination, and civil rights. they accused the republican party of being "afraid" to condemn slavery and the confederacy.

**key actions**:
- **hb 127**: a bill that was originally about providing extra sick days for teachers, but was amended by republicans to include "dei" (diversity, equity, and inclusion) provisions that the democrats opposed.

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
none mentioned.

**notable moments**:
- democrats accused republicans of trying to "hide" and "sneak through" the bill by bringing it up late at night.
- democrats said they were prepared to fight for "5-6 hours" to either defeat the bill or amend it, but were denied that opportunity.
- democrats criticized republicans for not allowing amendments that would have affirmed that slavery was a cause of the civil war and that evolution should be discussed.

**votes**:
no specific votes mentioned.

**attendance**:
no quorum notes provided.

**adjournment**:
no adjournment time or next session date mentioned. so up until last week this bill hb 127 was actually a bill to give teachers a

support it but the republicans decided that they wanted to take that away from
teachers and put on this dei bill supposedly was this called a dei bill which
has really taken us back to prior days of discrimination so let's kind of
get into the weeds for a second one of the things that we talked about was our
were not germane. they were very germane and they also had not created a substitute.
of all the amendments we had, all we did was try to add to this bill and actually make
it something that all georgians could actually kind of work through. but they didn't want
to do that. now the real deal to all of this, this bill takes us back. this is a sad day
for the georgia state senate. one of the saddest i've ever been in 10 years, quite frankly.
we heard one of my colleagues, senator lucas, talk about the fact what he grew up with,
what he's dealt with, senator magnum, others, nann orrah, others have fought the civil rights
movement and here we are again fighting the same movement again and it's really a
travesty that we'll be here doing these particular fights and i also believe
and i firmly believe this and one of the things i said in the well is they were
afraid of those amendments that actually talked about slavery and actually talked
about the confederate states of america because they could not vote on those

**overview**: the georgia legislative black caucus (glbc) held a press conference to address two pieces of "unacceptable" legislation (hb 127 and a bill impacting voting) and to stand in solidarity with the residents of sparta who are facing eminent domain actions by a private railroad company.

**key actions**:
- **hb 127**: described as an "attack on di programs in our state"
- **bill impacting voting**: works to reduce black voter turnout

**bills introduced (first reading)**: none mentioned

- rep. spencer fry, an associate member of the glbc, also spoke in support of the sparta residents, highlighting the importance of generational land ownership.
- larry raleigh of the ados advocacy foundation spoke in solidarity with the sparta landowners, decrying the history of land theft from black families.

**votes**: no recorded votes mentioned.

this press conference addressed the case of mario guevara, a journalist who has been detained by ice for over a month despite having the charges against him dropped. the detention of a journalist exercising his first amendment rights is seen as a troubling attack on press freedom.

none detected
