## overview
this session focused on considering resolutions to compensate individuals who were wrongfully incarcerated. several cases involving issues like self-defense, manufactured evidence, and juror misconduct were discussed.

## key actions
**hr 119**: resolution to compensate mario stinchcomb for 18 years of wrongful incarceration after he was exonerated by the fulton conviction integrity unit.  
**hr 118**: resolution to compensate michael woolfolk for wrongful incarceration after he was exonerated.  
**hr 129**: resolution to compensate daryl lee clark for 25 years of wrongful incarceration due to issues like manufactured evidence and witness coercion.

- hr 119 (stinchcomb compensation): passed

title: Rules Meeting Special Session of the 2025 Session

rules meeting special session of the 2025 session here is a summary of the georgia rules meeting special session of the 2025 session based on the transcript provided:

**overview**
the session focused on the introduction and consideration of several bills, primarily related to licensing requirements, venue regulations, homeowner associations, sexual assault kit retention, women's golf week designation, and rural hospital programs. there was some discussion and debate around one of the bills regarding potential discriminatory effects.

**key actions**
- **hb 512**: caps fees charged by homeowner associations and provides for alternate dispute resolution before liens can be placed.
- **hb 626**: extends the retention period for sexual assault kits from 20 to 30 years.
- **hb 718**: designates the first week of april as women's golf week in georgia.
- **hb 662**: allows rural emergency hospitals to participate in the georgia heart program.
- **hb 566**: protects artists from ai-generated replicas of their work without permission.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- hb 185: modernizes and streamlines licensing requirements for dieticians and nutritionists.
- hb 671: restricts minors from attending sexually explicit performances at venues.

key actions:
**hb 593**: provided that future elections for the office of probate judge of baker county shall be nonpartisan.
**hb 647**: allowed the city of mulberry to expand into a representative's district, adding 45 parcels to the city limits.

votes:
- hb 593 passed unanimously.
- hb 647 passed with one opposed vote.

title: Rules Meeting for Day 28 of the 2025 Session
text:
rules meeting for day 28 of the 2025 session here is a summary of the georgia rules meeting for day 28 of the 2025 session:

**overview**: this session featured a variety of bills being considered, including measures related to voting, black women's history, age discrimination, recovery support services, student loan forgiveness for veterinary technicians, and enforcement of transit lanes in atlanta.

**key actions**:
- **hb 502**: allows parents with young children to go to the front of the line when voting.
- **hb 146**: designates april as black women's history month.
- **hb 10**: removes arrest photos of those never convicted from "remove for pay" websites.
- **hb 311**: removes the age cap of 70 for working individuals.
- **hb 657**: certifies peer specialists and defines recovery community organizations.
- **hb 217**: extends a dual achievement program allowing high school dropouts to earn diplomas and technical certificates.
- **hb 88**: provides student loan forgiveness for veterinary technicians.
- **hb 638**: allows marta to use cameras to enforce bus rapid transit lanes.
- **hb 442**: allows students 25 days of school absence for film industry work.

**bills introduced (first reading)**: no new bills were introduced during this session.

- the session opened with a prayer, acknowledging the "busy, stressful" day.
- the chair reminded presenters to provide bill numbers and page locations to expedite the process.
- several bills were noted as having been perfected or recommended by the speaker pro tem.

**votes**:
- hb 502, hb 146, hb 10, hb 311, hb 657, hb 217, hb 88, hb 638, and hb 442 all passed with no recorded opposition.

**attendance**: quorum was met, and the session proceeded without noted attendance issues.

title: House PM Meeting 2 for Day 28 of the 2025 Session
text:
house pm meeting 2 for day 28 of the 2025 session here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia house pm meeting 2 for day 28 of the 2025 session:

## overview
the session focused on passing several bills, including hb 579 to modernize professional licensing in georgia, hb 549 to extend the reimbursement window for law enforcement training expenses, and hb 150 to require quarterly reports on foreign funding to state universities. there was some debate around the scope and approach of hb 150.

## key actions
**hb 579**: provides better constituent services and modernizes professional licensing in georgia.
**hb 549**: extends the reimbursement window for law enforcement training expenses from 15 to 36 months.
**hb 150**: requires the university system to report quarterly on funding received from "foreign countries of concern."

## bills introduced (first reading)
none mentioned.

## notable moments

the session focused on reconsidering a rural physician tax credit bill that had passed out of the committee previously but failed to get a full floor vote before the last session ended. the committee discussed updating the bill's language, including adding dentists to the tax credit and potentially updating the rural county definition to use more recent census data.

quorum present

title: Senator Harrell | GCDD Press Conference | 02/07/2024
text:
senator harrell | gcdd press conference | 02/07/2024 here is a structured summary of the georgia senator harrell | gcdd press conference | 02/07/2024 session:

**overview:** this press conference focused on important legislative priorities for supporting georgians with intellectual and developmental disabilities (idd). key topics included passing a bill to create an idd innovation commission, fully funding a service provider rate study, and ending the waitlist for medicaid home and community-based services waivers.

**key actions:**
**sb 198:** establishes an idd innovation commission to develop solutions for long-term challenges faced by georgians with idd.

**bills introduced (first reading):** none mentioned.

**notable moments:**
- senator harrell provided historical context on the 25-year supreme court ruling and 16-year settlement agreement to support idd community living.
- advocates, including self-advocate dorothy harris and provider diane willis, spoke passionately about the need for the legislation and increased funding.

**votes:** sb 198 passed the senate health and human services committee unanimously.

**attendance:** no legislators were specifically noted as being present.

**adjournment:** no formal adjournment noted, this was a press conference. good morning everyone and welcome to wages and waivers day. it's always great to see you
here at the capitol. it's so important that you make the effort to get here and i know
it's hard to get here. here's why it's important to be here today. it's been nearly 25 years
since the supreme court homestead decision,
which said that people with disabilities
have a right to state funded services
to live and thrive in their communities,
rather than being forced to live in institutions.
and it's been nearly 16 years since our state entered
into a settlement agreement with a department of justice
and committed to giving georgians with intellectual and developmental disabilities the support they need to live in their own homes and lead productive lives.
since then, it's been a long, slow road and truly to truly give this community what it needs to thrive.
i first became involved in this issue when i served in the house,
fighting to end the waiting list for medicaid waivers,
and when i came back to the senate 14 years later,
the medicaid home and community-based services waiting list
was still there and was longer.
i always tell my constituents that when they want something
done in this building, you've got to be loud.
we've made some progress in georgia with idd issues in recent years because this community
has shown up and been loud and because you've been loud, we increased funding for waivers
from approximately 100 per year to 500.
we passed senate bill 610 to make sure georgia did reimbursement rate studies every four
years so that wages for our service providers kept pace with the markets.
senator john albers and i co-sponsored a senate study committee on georgians with intellectual
and developmental disabilities and we heard from hundreds of advocates, parents, caregivers,
experts and service providers all over georgia about what we need for our
states. thanks to the study committee, we now have a road map to finally deliver
on the promise that georgia made 16 years ago

1/23/2024 senate committee on education and youth here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia 1/23/2024 senate committee on education and youth session:

### overview
the session focused on two notable bills related to education funding and school choice. key actions included passing bills to allow impact fees for fast-growing school districts and introducing a constitutional amendment to enable those impact fees.

### key actions
**sb 147**: the boundless opportunities for georgia students act, which would allow students to seek public education options outside their home district.
**sb 208**: enabling legislation for a constitutional amendment (sr 189) to allow counties with fast-growing school districts to levy impact fees for capital construction.
**sr 189**: constitutional amendment to allow counties with fast-growing school districts to levy impact fees for capital construction.

### bills introduced (first reading)
none noted in the transcript.

- senator dolezal provided detailed explanation of the impact fee legislation and the rationale behind it.
- committee members asked questions about the potential impact and reach of the impact fee bill.
- senator steele reintroduced the boundless opportunities for georgia students act.

### votes
- sb 208 (impact fee enabling legislation): passed unanimously.
- sr 189 (constitutional amendment for impact fees): passed unanimously.

### attendance
no specific quorum details provided.

the georgia senate committee on judiciary held a hearing on january 22, 2024 to consider house bill 30, which codifies a definition of anti-semitism based on the international holocaust remembrance alliance (ihra) definition. the session featured extensive debate and public testimony on the merits of the bill.

title: Sen. Elena Parent Press Conference on Reproductive Rights | 2-28-2024
text:
sen. elena parent press conference on reproductive rights | 2-28-2024 here is a summary of the key points from the georgia sen. elena parent press conference on reproductive rights:

**overview**
sen. elena parent addressed growing concerns around restrictions on reproductive healthcare, including the potential overturning of the constitutional right to contraception. she introduced two bills to codify the rights to contraception and ivf in georgia law.

**key actions**
- **right to contraception act**: codifies the right to choose when to start or expand a family through contraception.
- **right to ivf act**: establishes that human eggs or embryos outside the body are not considered children under state law.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- right to contraception act
- right to ivf act

**notable moments**
- sen. parent expressed concern that no republican colleagues were willing to co-sponsor the bills, indicating partisan disagreement on these reproductive rights issues.
- rep. marvin lim, a catholic, spoke in support of the right to contraception, noting its importance for family planning and public health.

title: 01/22/2024 Sen. Butler & Rep. Beverly Press Conference Commemorating Roe v. Wade Decision
text:
01/22/2024 sen. butler & rep. beverly press conference commemorating roe v. wade decision here is a structured markdown summary of the key points from the georgia 01/22/2024 sen. butler & rep. beverly press conference commemorating roe v. wade decision session:

## overview
the press conference commemorated the 51st anniversary of the roe v. wade supreme court decision that protected the constitutional right to abortion. democratic lawmakers discussed how the overturning of roe v. wade has stripped georgia women of reproductive freedom, and outlined their efforts to restore those rights through legislation and political action.

## key actions
none detected.

## bills introduced (first reading)
- **hb 75**: the reproductive freedom act (filed last session but not given a hearing)
- **sb 15**: the reproductive freedom act (filed last session but not given a hearing)

## notable moments
- democratic lawmakers shared personal stories about the importance of abortion access and the impact of georgia's near-total abortion ban.
- rep. beverly discussed her own experience having an abortion for medical reasons and the devastating impact the ban would have had on her family.
- democrats accused republican leadership of silencing citizens and refusing to allow a hearing on the reproductive freedom act.
- democrats announced they will hold their own public hearing on hb 75 across the street from the capitol, since republican leadership won't allow them to use a committee room.

## votes
none detected.

## attendance
no quorum notes.

no adjournment details provided. good afternoon, and hello to my democratic colleagues who have taken the time out of their
busy schedule to join us today, to observe the anniversary of roe versus wade.
fifty-one years ago, on january 22nd, 1973, the supreme court issued a landmark decision
in roe versus wade protecting a woman's constitutional right to choose.
the case reaffirmed basic principles of equality reinforced the fundamental right to privacy
and enabled women in this country to make deeply personal decisions, free from political
interference.
since roe was overturned by the supreme court justices that were handpicked by republican politicians,
we've seen countless horrifying stories of women across this country, denied life-saving
care and doctors threatened with prosecution for simply doing their job.
this should not be happening, not here in georgia, not anywhere in this nation.
who would have thought that our granddaughters would be worst off than their grandmothers?
the state of reproductive freedom in georgia at this particular time is untenable.
this is about our freedom to decide when, where and with whom to have a family.
i for one believe that a woman has a right to make that decision for herself.
republicans believe politicians have the right to make our most personal decisions based
on their values.
we believe in a freedom to make our own decisions based on our faith and our values.
a woman forced to deliver a baby is over 10 times more likely to die.
one in 50 pregnant women who have an ectopic pregnancy could die because the fetus has
implanted itself somewhere where it doesn't belong.
look, call me pro-life, pro-choice or pro-commonsense.
i just believe the government should not be telling a woman or a couple when they should
or shouldn't start a family based on someone else's interpretation of the scripture.
they believe fertilized eggs are people and they call themselves pro-life, but vote against
the lives of real babies and children.

## overview
the transcript discusses a report titled "sheltering in justice" released by the southern poverty law center (splc) action fund, which calls for georgia to stop criminalizing people experiencing homelessness. the report highlights the human impact of these harmful policies, including personal stories like that of 80-year-old ms. sylvia and entertainer jerry hertz.

no bills were mentioned as being passed or referred.

we are very excited to be here today to announce the launch of our latest report titled sheltering in justice.
this report is the result of a year-long collaboration with many of the advocates that you see here today as we call for our state to stop criminalizing people experiencing homelessness, especially those who have been experiencing poverty for a long time.
first, you were here from the author of this report, my colleague gina azito thompson, who is a policy analyst with the southern poverty law center.

analyst. i'm also the author of our new report sheltering and justice, a call for georgia
to stop criminalizing people experiencing homelessness. i'm honored to be here today
with these esteemed guests to discuss the issue of georgia's harmful practice of criminalizing
people experiencing homelessness. housing is a human right in access to safe and stable
housing is essential to a safe and vibrant community, state, and country. yet the rising
cost of housing and lack of supportive services mean that many across the state, the majority
of whom are people of color, especially black people, are deprived of housing and subsequently
experience homelessness. importantly, this is an urgent matter, both in georgia and across
the country. in fact, a recent harvard report found that more than half of renters could
not afford to pay their rent in 2022. and, because of these harmful laws, people experiencing

title: Sen. Islam Parkes Press Conference | 02/22/2024
text:

state senator nebula assam parks held a press conference highlighting three bills she has introduced to provide tax relief for georgia families - eliminating the sales tax on menstrual products, providing a tax break for baby supplies in the first three years, and reinstating the sales tax holiday for school supplies. she contrasts these bills with the legislature's prioritization of a gun tax holiday, arguing that the state should focus on supporting families rather than firearms.

key actions:
no bills passed or referred during this press conference.

bills introduced (first reading):
- **sb 51**: eliminate sales tax on menstrual products
- **sb 372**: provide tax break for baby supplies in first 3 years
- **sb 527**: reinstate sales tax holiday for school supplies

- she drew on her personal background growing up in a working-class family to emphasize the importance of these tax relief measures.
- she criticized the legislature for prioritizing a gun tax holiday over bills that would directly benefit georgia's families and children.

text:
sen. jackson | press conference | 02/07/2024 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia sen. jackson | press conference | 02/07/2024 session:

## overview
the press conference focused on supporting hb 1014, a bill that would prohibit the execution of individuals with intellectual disabilities in georgia. the bill has bipartisan support and is seen as an important step towards a more just criminal justice system in the state.

## key actions
**hb 1014**: prohibits the execution of individuals with intellectual disabilities in georgia.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected.

## notable moments
- senator kim jackson, representative workhizer, and other co-sponsors of hb 1014 spoke in support of the bill.
- faith leaders, including bishop ned slesinger from the archdiocese of atlanta, also voiced their support for the legislation.
- representatives deborah silcox and matt reeves, who are co-sponsors of the bill, made brief remarks.

## votes
none detected.

## attendance
quorum was present, as evidenced by the number of legislators and faith leaders in attendance.

## adjournment
the press conference concluded, but no information was provided about the next legislative session. so i'd like to introduce senator reverend kim jackson.
well, good afternoon.
today we stand to say no to executing people who have intellectual disabilities.
today we stand to say we recognize that people who have intellectual disabilities
are not able to make conscious decisions that should lead to their execution.
and today we stand together as a collective, as clergy, as people of faith,
and people of simple, good moral character, who are saying no more in this state.
the state of georgia has worked really hard over the years to be a forefront
and a leader around certain issues within the death penalty.
but this is one place where we fall in short.
we continue to execute people who simply should not be on death row.
and so today i am proud to work alongside our house representative bill workhouseer on
this bill that will change the tide for georgia and help move us to a more just society.
a society where we recognize that people who went to special education their entire lives,
who we know have been documented as having intellectual disabilities, that we are going
to be a state that has good moral character and that we will not execute them.
so i am grateful to my colleague for sponsoring hb 1014 and i look forward to getting across
the chambers to the senate where we can support it and get it all the way across the finish
line.
with that, i'd like to introduce representative workhizer.

**overview**
the press conference focused on literacy and education reform efforts in georgia, particularly around the georgia early literacy act (hb 538) and senate bill 464. there was a strong emphasis on the importance of high-quality assessment tools and universal screeners to identify struggling readers early.

**key actions**
- **hb 538**: the georgia early literacy act, which mandates the use of evidence-based literacy curricula and structured literacy instruction. 
- **sb 464**: a related bill focused on literacy assessments and screeners.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
no new bills were introduced during this press conference.

**notable moments**
- rep. bethy ballard, the sponsor of hb 538, discussed the importance of early identification of struggling readers and providing intensive instruction.
- sen. clint dixon emphasized the decline in student achievement scores and the need for better assessment tools to empower parents.
- sen. hickman proposed an amendment to sb 464 to require a universal, free screener to be used by all schools statewide for consistency and comparability.

no votes were taken during this press conference.

**attendance**
the press conference was well-attended by members of the media and other interested parties.

title: 07-24-2024 Sen. Nikki Merritt Press Conference on AP African American Studies in Georgia schools
text:
07-24-2024 sen. nikki merritt press conference on ap african american studies in georgia schools overview:
this press conference was held by georgia state senator nikki merritt and other legislators to condemn the decision to remove the ap african american studies course from the state's curriculum. they argue that this course is essential for teaching the full history of the united states and providing opportunities for students, especially black students, to engage with their heritage.

key actions:

11/7/2023 | red tape rollback press conference | lt. governor burt jones, sen. brian strickland,... here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia 11/7/2023 red tape rollback press conference:

**overview**:
the lt. governor and republican senate leaders highlighted legislative plans for the upcoming session to reduce regulatory burdens and "red tape" for small businesses in georgia, focusing on occupational licensing reforms.

**key actions**:
- **sb 157**: reduces barriers to employment for individuals with criminal records by creating a uniform process for how their records are considered by licensing boards.

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
none detected.

**notable moments**:
- lt. governor jones and senate leaders, including majority leader gooch and committee chairs dolezal and walker, expressed support for the "red tape rollback" initiative to assist small businesses.
- sen. strickland provided details on sb 157, which unanimously passed the senate last year but stalled in the house. he emphasized the bill's importance in addressing workforce needs and helping formerly incarcerated individuals become productive members of society.
- sen. walker discussed his role chairing a study committee on occupational licensing, noting the need to address workforce shortages and regulatory barriers facing businesses.

none recorded.

quorum present, with lt. governor and key senate republican leaders in attendance.

3/16/2023- senate committee on higher education here is a summary of the georgia senate committee on higher education session on 3/16/2023:

**overview**:
this session focused on discussing and passing several bills related to higher education, including adjustments to scholarship requirements and expanding eligibility for tuition grants.

**key actions**:
- **hb326**: expanded eligibility for the georgia tuition equalization grant to include an additional nursing school
- **hb607**: aligned the act test score requirement for the zell miller scholarship to match the sat score requirement
- **hb932**: passed out of committee

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
no new bills were introduced during this session.

**notable moments**:
- discussion around ensuring the zell miller scholarship standards are not lowered by aligning the act and sat requirements
- praise for the simplicity and intent of hb607 to create fairness for students taking the act versus sat

**votes**:
- hb607 passed the committee unanimously
- hb326 was discussed but no vote was taken

**attendance**:
a quorum was present, with members waiting for one additional senator to return before proceeding.

**adjournment**:
the session was adjourned after the committee completed its business. the next meeting date was not specified. you

title: 8/9/2023 - Joint Study Committee on Dual Enrollment and Highly Skilled Talent
text:

**overview**
the session focused on the healthcare workforce and dual enrollment programs, with legislators highlighting the success of the college and career academy partnership with phoebe in albany, georgia. the committee aims to find ways to expand dual enrollment and develop more highly skilled talent at younger ages across the state.

**key actions**
no major bills were passed or referred during this session.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
none mentioned.

- representative matt dubnik, chair of the house appropriations subcommittee on education, discussed the importance of developing georgia's workforce and challenged the committee to find ways to improve dual enrollment programs.
- the committee plans to hold a future meeting in newnan, georgia to focus on dual enrollment and manufacturing.

**votes**
no recorded votes mentioned.

**attendance**
quorum was met, with legislative leaders from across georgia in attendance.

title: 9/27/2023 Senate Study Committee on Occupational Licensing
text:
9/27/2023 senate study committee on occupational licensing here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senate study committee on occupational licensing session on 9/27/2023:

## overview
this session focused on the issues surrounding occupational licensing in georgia, including the burdensome requirements, barriers to entry, and economic impacts. the discussion highlighted previous legislative efforts to improve the system and explored potential options for further reform.

## key actions
**sb 157**: no details provided on this bill.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced.

## notable moments
- mark hyden from the r street institute provided an overview of occupational licensing challenges in georgia, including high fees, education/experience requirements, and the lack of demonstrable benefits to consumers.
- hyden acknowledged that some licensing is necessary but argued the system overall needs improvement to reduce barriers and increase competition.
- hyden highlighted previous legislative efforts to address issues, such as interstate licensure compacts and a law prohibiting license suspensions for student loan defaults.

## votes
no recorded votes mentioned.

## attendance
the committee chair noted the absence of senators halpern and vittardi, who were unavailable to attend.

## adjournment

title: 8/22/2023 - Senate Study Committee on Expanding Georgia's Workforce
text:
8/22/2023 - senate study committee on expanding georgia's workforce here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senate study committee on expanding georgia's workforce session on 8/22/2023:

## overview
this was the third meeting of the senate study committee on expanding georgia's workforce, convened by lt. governor bert jones. the committee is examining ways to address georgia's workforce needs and is planning to hold meetings across the state before submitting a final report and recommendations in november.

## key actions
none detected.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected.

## notable moments
- the committee chair, sen. john albers, welcomed the members and speakers, including representatives from the technical college system, georgia chamber of commerce, metro atlanta chamber, and state senators.
- lt. governor's office representative brad vaughn provided an overview of the committee's purpose - to find ways to make it easier for georgians to join the workforce and address the state's growing economic needs.
- the committee plans to hold additional meetings in commerce, dalton, and a final session at the state capitol in november.

## votes
none detected.

## attendance
quorum was present, with committee members in attendance.

title: 9-7-2023 Senator Colton Moore Press Conference
text:
9-7-2023 senator colton moore press conference here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia 9-7-2023 senator colton moore press conference:

## overview
this press conference by senator colton moore focused on criticizing fulton county district attorney fani willis and calling for a special legislative session to investigate her. senator moore accused willis of politicizing her office and misusing taxpayer funds, while also alleging a constitutional crisis due to a lack of checks and balances.

## key actions
none detected.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected.

## notable moments
- senator moore opened with a prayer led by "dr. king".
- moore declared this was not about partisan politics, but about protecting children and freedoms.
- moore called for governor kemp to visit his district and ask constituents if they want their tax dollars going to da willis.
- moore criticized willis for the issues at the fulton county jail and the pace of high-profile criminal cases.
- moore accused fellow senators of being "afraid to speak out" due to fear of willis.
- bruce lavalle, a close friend of donald trump, also spoke at the press conference, criticizing the current state of georgia politics.

title: 11/29/2023 Senate Committee on Reapportionment and Redistricting
text:
11/29/2023 senate committee on reapportionment and redistricting here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia 11/29/2023 senate committee on reapportionment and redistricting session:

## overview
the session focused on the process of redrawing senate district maps to comply with a court order requiring the creation of two additional majority-black districts in south metro atlanta. the committee chairs discussed their approach of meeting with affected senators, following traditional redistricting principles, and minimizing changes to existing districts as much as possible.

## key actions
no bills were passed or referred during this session.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced.

## notable moments
- committee chair senator shelley eckles thanked various individuals for their work and participation in the redistricting process.
- vice chair senator hatchett discussed the challenges of balancing the court order with senators' desires to keep their districts unchanged.
- the committee adopted the same rules and guidelines used in the 2023 legislative session.
- senator butler indicated he would present his redistricting proposal to the committee the following day.

## votes
the committee unanimously voted to:
- re-adopt the committee rules from the 2023 legislative session
- adopt the 2023-24 guidelines for the senate reapportionment and redistricting committee

## attendance
quorum was present, though the transcript did not provide specific attendance numbers.

## adjournment

title: Legislative Day 39 (Pt. 2)- 2023 Session - 3/27/23
text:
legislative day 39 (pt. 2)- 2023 session - 3/27/23 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia legislative day 39 (pt. 2) - 2023 session - 3/27/23 session:

## overview
the session focused on passing several bills, including measures related to absentee ballot applications, time off for early voting, additional judges for the superior courts, and restrictions on the use of certain social media platforms on state equipment.

## key actions
**hr 256**: not discussed
**sb 103**: senate agreed to house substitute, adding more licensure requirements and a process for conflicting claims related to the department of revenue.
**sb 129**: senate agreed to house substitute, revising language on absentee ballot applications and providing for time off for employees to advance vote.
**sb 66**: senate agreed to house substitute, providing for an additional judge for the superior courts of the atlantic judicial circuit.
**sb 211**: not discussed

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced.

## notable moments
- senator from the 8th presented sb 103, noting it was a request from the department of revenue.
- senator from the 25th presented sb 129, describing it as a "good housekeeping bill" to provide time off for early voting.
- senator from the 4th presented sb 66, explaining the house changed the start date for the new judge position.
- senator from the 31st presented sb 93, referring to it as the "tiktok bill" to restrict use of certain social media platforms on state equipment.

## votes
- sb 103 passed 43-4
- sb 129 passed 46-3
- sb 66 passed 53-0

## attendance
the senate excused the senators from the 12th and 22nd.

this session focused on the final report from the senate study committee on rural medical personnel recruitment. the committee discussed and debated several recommendations in the report, particularly around the role of certified nurse anesthetists (crnas) in rural healthcare delivery.

none detected.

## overview
this session involved the committee considering several bills, including legislation to address cold case homicides, an annual code revision bill, and a bill increasing penalties for arson of law enforcement vehicles. the committee took action on these bills and heard from legislators and other stakeholders.

## key actions
**hb 30**: bill to address cold case homicides by allowing families to request case reviews, requiring reporting on cold cases, and clarifying death certificate procedures. passed by committee substitute.
**hb 475**: annual code revision bill to repeal obsolete or unconstitutional code sections. passed unanimously.
**hb 500**: bill increasing penalties for arson of law enforcement vehicles. introduced and referred to committee.

- rep. silcox presented the annual code revision bill, hb 475.

- hb 475 (code revision): passed unanimously.

a quorum was present, and the committee proceeded with its agenda.

text:
8-14-2023 senate study committee on local option sales tax here is a summary of the key points from the georgia senate study committee on local option sales tax session:

**overview**
the session focused on discussing the local option sales tax structure in georgia, including the timeline and administration of these taxes. the committee heard from the georgia department of revenue on the various types of local sales taxes and the process for renegotiating the joint county and municipal sales tax every 10 years after the census.

**key actions**
no specific bills were discussed or acted upon.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
none detected.

**notable moments**
- the committee discussed the georgia supreme court's recent ruling that parties cannot litigate in court if they cannot reach an agreement during the required renegotiation process for the joint county and municipal sales tax.
- the department of revenue provided an overview of the different types of local sales taxes in georgia, including the joint county and municipal sales tax, consolidated government sales tax, and special district transportation sales tax.
- the department of revenue outlined the timeline for the renegotiation process that occurs every 10 years after the census, including the requirement to submit disputes to arbitration or mediation if an agreement is not reached within 60 days.

no votes were taken.

title: Legislative Day 36 - 2023 Session - 03/20/23
text:
legislative day 36 - 2023 session - 03/20/23 overview: the georgia legislative session on march 20, 2023 featured the introduction of several new bills and resolutions, as well as the recommittal of sr334 to the rules committee. notable legislation included bills related to city charters, tax exemptions, and school systems.

key actions:
**hr 334**: resolution changing the rules of the senate, recommitted to the rules committee
**hb 373, hb493, hb545, sb 140**: bills not explicitly mentioned in the transcript

bills introduced (first reading):
- sb 309: homestead exemption for city of hampton ad valorem taxes
- sb 310: new charter for city of powder springs
- sr 347: honoring life of mr. sean p. kornakian
- sr 352: committing atlanta public schools on 150th anniversary
- hb 597, hb 666, hb 695, hb 702, hb 703, hb 708, hb 709: various city charter and school system bills

- sr334 recommitted to rules committee (objection raised, motion passed)
